text: Your Monday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen to ‘The Daily’The latest on the president’s health.
From Opinion: Listen to ‘Sway’Kara Swisher meets the man behind America’s race for a vaccine.
Scientists and doctors were outraged that the president urged people not to be afraid of a disease that has killed nearly 210,000 Americans.
Since President Trump’s diagnosis, numerous associates have tested positive, but the White House has not aggressively investigated the outbreak.
President Trump’s health crisis was a chance to show a new, more empathetic stance, some advisers believed. But the candidate didn’t stick to the narrative.
In the case of Dr. Sean Conley, the White House physician, disobeying President Trump’s wishes could be seen as tantamount to insubordination.
At least three correspondents have tested positive for the coronavirus, along with the press secretary and two of her deputies.
The White House chief of staff objected to new guidelines that would almost certainly guarantee that no vaccine could be approved before the election.
After removing earlier guidance from its website, the agency cited evidence that indoor air can carry virus-laden particles.

Nearly One-Third of Covid Patients in Study Had Altered Mental StateThe hospitalized patients showed signs of deteriorating neurological function, ranging from confusion to coma-like unresponsiveness, research indicates.

Cuomo Won’t Approve Closing of Businesses in 9 Hard-Hit N.Y.C. AreasGov. Andrew Cuomo’s abrupt announcement caused confusion over the official response to virus spikes and threatened to deepen tensions with the mayor.

A Student Dies, and a Campus Gets Serious About CoronavirusCases are spiking at Appalachian State University in North Carolina, causing many students and faculty members to call for stronger safety measures.
‘The Coal Industry Is Back,’ Trump Proclaimed. It Wasn’t.The demise of coal-fired power plants in Arizona and Kentucky shows how the president failed to counter the forces decimating the industry.

Steven Mnuchin’s Deal Staved Off Catastrophe. Can He Make Another One?Even many Trump critics credit his Treasury secretary with rescuing the economy from the pandemic. Will he be able to do it again?
Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
Jennifer SeniorWhy Fox News Is Still in a Coronavirus BubbleHumans will do figure eights to make facts suit their fictions.
Paul KrugmanBidencare Would Be a Big DealDon’t dismiss it because it isn’t Medicare for All.
Bret StephensWish a President Well Who Doesn’t Wish You Well
Michelle GoldbergA White House Infected With Propaganda
Gus WezerekCan You Guess Trump’s Record?
The Editorial BoardThe American People Need the Truth
Lessons From Trump’s Own Case of Covid-19
Gail Collins and Bret StephensThere Is Too Much Happening
Jenni RussellAmerica, We Know What You’re Going Through
Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak‘They Chose to Stay Open and Fight’
Ruth MargalitLockdown Feels Pretty Different the Second Time Around
Those We’ve LostThe pandemic has taken an incalculable death toll. This series is designed to put names and faces to the numbers.
Nicole Kidman Leans Into the PainKidman stars in “The Undoing,” an HBO thriller debuting later this month. She talked to us about acting, emotion and making “Eyes Wide Shut.”

‘In 1973, I Yelled Out to Elston Howard, the Former Yankees Catcher’Spotting famous people on the street, a night outside the Met and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

Those We’ve LostThe pandemic has taken an incalculable death toll. This series is designed to put names and faces to the numbers.
Nicole Kidman Leans Into the PainKidman stars in “The Undoing,” an HBO thriller debuting later this month. She talked to us about acting, emotion and making “Eyes Wide Shut.”

‘In 1973, I Yelled Out to Elston Howard, the Former Yankees Catcher’Spotting famous people on the street, a night outside the Met and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
Listen to ‘The Daily’The latest on the president’s health.
From Opinion: Listen to ‘Sway’Kara Swisher meets the man behind America’s race for a vaccine.
The Neediest Cases FundThese New Yorkers found help to take their next steps.
Scientists and doctors were outraged that the president urged people not to be afraid of a disease that has killed nearly 210,000 Americans.
Since President Trump’s diagnosis, numerous associates have tested positive, but the White House has not aggressively investigated the outbreak.
President Trump’s health crisis was a chance to show a new, more empathetic stance, some advisers believed. But the candidate didn’t stick to the narrative.
In the case of Dr. Sean Conley, the White House physician, disobeying President Trump’s wishes could be seen as tantamount to insubordination.
Campaigning in Florida, Joe Biden said he “wasn’t surprised” that President Trump contracted the virus.
At least three correspondents have tested positive for the coronavirus, along with the press secretary and two of her deputies.
The White House chief of staff objected to new guidelines that would almost certainly guarantee that no vaccine could be approved before the election.
President Trump remains at a precarious point, doctors have warned. Here’s how the immune system responds to the virus.
After removing earlier guidance from its website, the agency cited evidence that indoor air can carry virus-laden particles.
A study of hospitalized Covid-19 patients in the Chicago area showed that nearly a third of those patients had some form of altered mental ability. Erin Schaff/The New York Times

Cuomo Won’t Approve Closing of Businesses in 9 Hard-Hit N.Y.C. AreasGov. Andrew Cuomo’s abrupt announcement caused confusion over the official response to virus spikes and threatened to deepen tensions with the mayor.
Israel’s Second Lockdown Fuels Protests, Violence and ConfusionLast month, the country reimposed nationwide measures. But the decision has led to chaotic scenes and criticism.

Kamala Harris’s Doubleheader: A Debate and Hearings With High StakesShe is viewed as a gifted cross-examiner whose instincts for verbal combat are one of her greatest political strengths, but this is a new challenge.
The Supreme Court revived a South Carolina law that requires absentee ballots to be accompanied by a witness’s signature.
‘The Coal Industry Is Back,’ Trump Proclaimed. It Wasn’t.The demise of coal-fired power plants in Arizona and Kentucky shows how the president failed to counter the forces decimating the industry.
